properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of hot weather is expected. Daytime high temperatures near 30 degrees Celsius will continue today and Friday. Overnight low temperatures near 18 degrees Celsius will provide little relief from the heat. Cooler temperatures with showers or thunderstorms are expected to arrive Friday evening. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-10T11:41:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-09T19:42:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3377816694.2020
Area: Attawapiskat, Fort Hope - Lansdowne House - Ogoki, Fort Albany, Moosonee
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A heat wave continues. A warm and humid air mass over Southern Quebec will persist over the next few days. The heat wave will continue north of Montreal. Temperatures will exceed the 30-degree mark during the day and will not fall below 18 degrees at night. Combined values of the temperature and the humidity will give a humidex value of 40. These conditions are likely to persist into Saturday. During times of high heat, your health and the health of your family and friends can deteriorate rapidly. The ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux du Québec, in cooperation with Environment and Climate Change Canada, recommends that you protect yourself from the effects of the heat by taking the following actions: Drink 6 to 8 glasses of water per day. As appropriate, follow your physician's instructions regarding the amount of fluid to drink; Avoid alcoholic beverages; Spend at least 2 hours a day in an air conditioned or cool place; Take at least one cool shower or bath per day, or cool your skin several times per day with wet towels; Limit physical activity; Wear light clothes. Be sure to: Never leave a child or a baby alone in a vehicle or a poorly ventilated room, even for a few minutes; Check on your loved ones, especially those who are vulnerable or living alone. If you have any questions regarding your health, call Info-Santé by dialing 8-1-1 or ask a health care provider. In case of emergency, call 9-1-1. For more information, visit the Government of Quebec's Portail santé mieux-être at www.sante.gouv.qc.ca. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-10T11:44:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-09T19:45:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4090591047.2020
Area: Gatineau

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of hot weather will continue through the rest of this week. Daytime high temperatures in excess of 30 degrees Celsius, with humidex values in the high thirties to low forties, are expected this week. Overnight lows near 20 degrees Celsius are also expected through this period, providing little relief from the heat. A slightly cooler airmass may move into the area this weekend, however there is considerable uncertainty and the conditions may persist for a few areas into Saturday. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. Never leave people or pets inside a parked vehicle. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-10T11:46:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-09T19:47:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3345008775.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heat event continues until the weekend. Inland from the Great Lakes, daytime high temperatures near 30 degrees Celsius will accompany humidex values in the mid thirties until the weekend. Overnight low temperatures in the upper teens are also expected during this period. Slightly lower temperatures are expected this weekend, although they may still reach the high twenties. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. Never leave people or pets inside a parked vehicle. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts, damaging hail and heavy rain this evening. Boaters may be surprised by strong wind gusts over bodies of water. ### Very large hail can damage property, break windows, dent vehicles and cause serious injury. Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-10T07:59:24-00:00

properties.Title: Update: Flood Warning Continued For The Little Saskatchewan River
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure’s Hydrologic Forecast Centre Flood Warning for the Little Saskatchewan River continues. The Flood Warning for the Whitemud River has ended. The Little Saskatchewan River is above flood stage and low-lying land near the rivers are affected. If you are in the affected area, be watchful as local waterways are expected to rise quickly and may cause flooding. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Use caution when driving on all roads as road conditions may have changed. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by local authorities and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Stay tuned to local media for updates. Up to date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca
Expires: 2020-07-10T16:00:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2020-07-09T15:00:34-05:00, E1F05D26-D908-A10F-9A45-D4B07E11B640
Area: Little Saskatchewan River

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 6:35 p.m. ADT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. A line of thunderstorms over the northwest will sweep southeast, giving mainly heavy rain, currently with some small hail. Maximum rainfall rates: in excess of 25 mm/h. Total rainfall: 20 to 50 mm Maximum hail size: near 2 cm. Maximum wind gusts up to 90 km/h : Locations: A line of thunderstorms extending from Neguac southwest to Renous, moving southeast at 45 km/h. Time span: ending by this evening. Remarks: A line of three thunderstorms is moving southeast across Miramichi County, with the highest threat for rainfall amounts, followed by hail, and some gusty winds. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 5:23 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to toonie size hail and heavy rain. This broken line of severe thunderstorms is located from 55 kilometres southwest of Peawanuck to 130 kilometres east of Webequie to 120 kilometres north of Mammamattawa, moving northeast at 70 km/h. Locations impacted include: Spruce Lake and Opinnagau Lake. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads.
Expires: 2020-07-10T00:22:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-09T21:24:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0763999951.2020
Area: Webequie, Fort Hope - Lansdowne House - Ogoki
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Potential rainfall rates: in excess of 25 mm/h. Total rainfall: possibly in excess of 50 mm Potential wind gusts:70-90 km/h Locations: northern and eastern New Brunswick and Prince County, Prince Edward Island. Time span: into this evening. Remarks: Scattered thunderstorms have developed and are expected to continue into this evening. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-10T01:59:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-09T21:50:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2428607107.2020
Area: Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 5:36 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a cluster of severe thunderstorms capable of producing strong wind gusts and heavy rain. This cluster of severe thunderstorms is located from 9 kilometres west of Feversham to 11 kilometres southwest of Dundalk to Mount Forest, moving east at 30 km/h. Locations impacted include: Dundalk, Keldon, Corbetton, Badjeros and Melancthon. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing heavy rain. Potential rainfall rates: 25 mm per hour or higher in thunderstorms. Potential wind gusts: locally 70 km/h or higher in thunderstorms. Locations: Cartwright to Black Tickle. Time span: this evening. Remarks: A strong thunderstorm cell just northwest of Cartwright is moving southeastward at 40 km/h. Localized downpours and gusty winds may accompany this storm cell as it tracks across the region. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-07-10T03:51:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-09T21:55:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3771915258.2020
Area: Cartwright to Black Tickle
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 4:42 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a cluster of severe thunderstorms capable of producing strong wind gusts and heavy rain. This cluster of severe thunderstorms is located from 12 kilometres east of Durham to Mount Forest to 6 kilometres east of Palmerston, moving east at 40 km/h. The main threat with this cluster of thunderstorms continues to be heavy rainfall rates of 50 mm per hour. Locations impacted include: Yeovil, Maple Lane, Kenilworth, Conn, Hopeville, Egerton and Damascus. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 5:01 p.m. CDT (5:01 p.m. EST), Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. This line of severe thunderstorms is located from 20 kilometres northwest of Kinloch Lake to 25 kilometres north of Lake St. Joseph, moving northeast at 75 km/h. Locations impacted include: Pickle Lake, Kinloch Lake, Littleford Lake, Leckey Lake, Williams Lake, Nanos Lake, Deshane Lake, Otoskwin Lake and Central Patricia. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads.
Expires: 2020-07-10T00:55:46-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 2:23 p.m. MDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. The severe thunderstorm is located near Edson and is moving east at 35 km/h. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Thunderstorms will develop this afternoon and move eastwards this evening. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-10T08:13:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-09T19:59:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0886255429.2020
